Q: "It is not always easy to see which chemicals are contained in our consumer products. The following argument pertains to this question: To start with, it is not the case that Titanium dioxide is an ingredient of BRONZER POWDER. Now, being an ingredient of BRONZER POWDER is necessary for being an ingredient of Washout Shampoo. All this entails that it is not the case that Titanium dioxide is an ingredient of Washout Shampoo."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:

Q: "It is not always easy to see who is related to whom -- and in which ways. The following argument pertains to this question: First premise: Every son of Rich is an uncle of Armando. Second premise: Whoever is neither a schoolmate of Ron nor a close friend of Jose is a son of Rich. So, necessarily, whoever is none of this: a schoolmate of Ron or close friend of Jose, is an uncle of Armando."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:

Q: "Is Fred a cousin of Robert? Is Joe related to Bob? In large families, it is sometimes difficult to keep track of all one's relatives. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: To start with, Edward is not a schoolmate of Randy. Now, every son of Tony is neither a schoolmate of Randy nor a brother of George. Moreover, it is not the case that Edward is a brother of George. In consequence, it is false that Edward is a son of Tony."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:

Q: "Is Titanium oxide an ingredient of my washing power? Which chemicals does my perfume contain? It is really difficult to keep track of all chemicals one is regularly exposed to. The following argument seeks to clarify some such relations: First, every ingredient of OH Cabana Boy is not an ingredient of Revlon Blush Stick or not an ingredient of Disco Nail Polish. Second, whatever is not an ingredient of Revlon Blush Stick is an ingredient of Happy Anniversary. Third, nothing is neither an ingredient of Disco Nail Polish nor an ingredient of Happy Anniversary. Therefore, everything that is an ingredient of OH Cabana Boy is an ingredient of Happy Anniversary, too."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:

Q: "Here comes a perfectly valid argument: To start with, every regular user of Neutrogena shampoo is an owner of a Protex soap. Now, Janice is an owner of a Protex soap. We may conclude: Janice is a regular user of Neutrogena shampoo."
 Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:

All this entails that whoever is not a sister of Doris is a great-grandmother of Shanika."

A:

Q: "Consumer research aims at understanding whether users of some products also tend to consume other ones, or not.  Is the argument, given the explicitly stated premises, deductively valid or invalid?
A:
